content.raw: I still think there's one too many box classes, but I understand we're trying to move fast.
content.html: I still think there's one too many box classes, but I understand we're trying to move fast.

update.description:
Moved `Box` to AxisAlignedBox, and implemented a new templatized Box class that is not axis-aligned and contains material properties.

I did not make changes, other than naming, to `AxisAlignedBox`. We can look into inheritance or composition with `Box` in a different PR.

I did not deprecate the existing `Box` class on purpose. There is a note in the migration guide.
update.title: Mat set from box boxclass

content.raw: The Box class does not have a pose, which the OrientedBox has. The `Box` class is the most generic box.
content.html: The Box class does not have a pose, which the OrientedBox has. The Box class is the most generic box.

content.raw: Thanks, but it's still not clear to me why we still need the `Box` class. `OrientedBox` has boxes that **are not aligned**, `AxisAlignedBox` has boxes that **are aligned**. What's the `Box` class for?
content.html: Thanks, but it's still not clear to me why we still need the Box class. OrientedBox has boxes that are not aligned, AxisAlignedBox has boxes that are aligned. What's the Box class for?

content.raw: Update axis-aligned documentation:
content.html: Update axis-aligned documentation:

content.html: See pull request #269

content.raw: This function doesn’t do the same thing as `SetDensityFromMass`. Take a look at the implementation.

content.raw: I'm a bit confused now as to why we need 3 `Box` classes. It would be nice to add some documentation explaining the use case for each of them.

content.html: In that case it could conflict with the documentation of SetSize, right?

content.raw: Should the other functions mention that the box dimensions are in meters?
content.html: Should the other functions mention that the box dimensions are in meters?

content.raw: Hmm. This box is not associated with any axis. The user is free to decide if length is oriented along X, Y, or Z.
content.html: Hmm. This box is not associated with any axis. The user is free to decide if length is oriented along X, Y, or Z.

content.raw: const params? The same goes for several other functions taking `Precision`
content.html: const params? The same goes for several other functions taking Precision

content.raw: I see the rest of the documentation has a mapping, it could be ok to leave this one the way it is
content.html: I see the rest of the documentation has a mapping, it could be ok to leave this one the way it is

content.raw: The words `length`, `width` and `height` can be confusing unless it is predefined which axes they belong to. What do you think of explicitly mentioning the axes which they refer to?
content.html: The words length, width and height can be confusing unless it is predefined which axes they belong to. What do you think of explicitly mentioning the axes which they refer to?

content.raw: Thanks, I didn’t see the OrientedBox class. I’ll add material properties to that in a separate PR.
content.html: Thanks, I didn’t see the OrientedBox class. I’ll add material properties to that in a separate PR.

This addresses issue #77.
